verses.text: The words of the Preacher, son of David, king in Jerusalem:
verses.comment: The 'Preacher' (Hebrew: Qoheleth) is often understood as Solomon. Tradition connects this book to the wisest king, highlighting its authority and wisdom-teaching. Echoes of Proverbs and the kingly legacy underline the role of divinely guided leadership.

verses.text: "Vanity of vanities," says the Preacher. "Vanity of vanities! All is vanity."
verses.comment: The phrase 'vanity of vanities' expresses extreme futility or emptiness. The repetition in Hebrew denotes superlative emphasis, signaling the ultimate emptiness of life disconnected from God. See also the Psalmist’s similar reflections.

verses.text: What advantage does a person gain from all his labor at which he toils under the sun?
verses.comment: 'Under the sun' emphasizes life from a purely earthly perspective. The text asks about enduring value apart from eternal things—a question that finds its full answer in the greater revelation of Christ and the hope of resurrection.

verses.text: A generation passes away, and another generation comes, but the earth remains forever.
verses.comment: The contrast between fleeting human life and the lasting earth points to humanity’s dependence on something beyond this world. This reflects the tension between temporal and eternal, fulfilled in God’s plan to renew creation.

verses.text: The sun rises, and the sun sets, and hurries back to the place where it rises.
verses.comment: The repetition of natural cycles underscores the monotony of earthly existence. Early Christian writers saw these cycles as types pointing beyond themselves to God's greater mysteries and the coming of a new dawn in Christ.

verses.text: The wind blows toward the south and turns to the north; around and around it goes, on its circuit the wind returns.
verses.comment: Nature’s ceaseless cycles hint at the longing for something greater than earthly repetition—a longing fulfilled in the Kingdom of Heaven, which is unending and not bound by earthly cycles.

verses.text: All streams run into the sea, but the sea is never full. To the place where the streams flow, there they return to flow again.
verses.comment: This verse anticipates the scientific understanding of the water cycle and expresses frustration at the world’s unending motion. Spiritually, it can symbolize the human search for fulfillment which ultimately finds rest only in God.

verses.text: All things are wearisome; no one can express it. The eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with hearing.
verses.comment: Deep restlessness and desire point to a longing for the infinite. This aligns with classic themes: that only the ultimate truth and union with God can satisfy the deepest human hunger.

verses.text: What has been is what will be, and what has been done is what will be done. There is nothing new under the sun.
verses.comment: Human experience repeats itself due to the fallen state of the world. However, the coming of Christ breaks this cycle by inaugurating a new creation (see 2 Cor. 5:17).

verses.text: Is there anything of which it is said, 'Look! This is new'? It has already existed in the ages before us.
verses.comment: Christians later see in this recognition of earthly limits the need for a supernatural renewal, fulfilled in the mystery of the incarnation—something utterly new brought by God Himself.

verses.text: There is no remembrance of former generations; neither will those to come be remembered by those who follow them.
verses.comment: This verse reflects the limitations of human memory and legacy, but foreshadows the promise that God remembers His people for eternity (see Luke 23:42-43).

verses.text: I, the Preacher, was king over Israel in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Reiterates the Solomonic authorship. The kingly office was seen as anointed and holding unique wisdom—an image later fulfilled perfectly in Jesus, the true King.

verses.text: I applied my heart to seek and to search out by wisdom all that is done under heaven. It is a burdensome task God has given to the children of man to be afflicted with.
verses.comment: Here is the vocation to search for wisdom—a recurring biblical theme. All human searching apart from God ultimately proves burdensome, echoing humanity’s need for divine guidance through sacred tradition.

verses.text: I have seen all the works done under the sun, and behold, all is vanity and a chasing after the wind.
verses.comment: Repeated use of 'vanity' and 'chasing the wind' intensifies the futility described. Only God’s revelation through Scripture and the apostolic tradition gives lasting substance to human aspirations.

verses.text: What is crooked cannot be made straight, and what is lacking cannot be counted.
verses.comment: This points to the brokenness of the fallen world, which only God can restore. The prophecy of making the crooked straight is later fulfilled by the forerunner of Christ in the New Testament.

verses.text: I said in my heart, "I have grown and increased in wisdom more than all who were before me in Jerusalem. My heart has understood much wisdom and knowledge."
verses.comment: 'Wisdom' is highly prized. The fullness of wisdom is found in the Logos, the Word made flesh, who gives Himself fully to the Church as the wisdom from above (1 Cor. 1:30).

verses.text: And I set my heart to know wisdom, and to know madness and folly. I perceived that this also is a chasing after the wind.
verses.comment: Ecclesiastes recognizes that merely intellectual pursuits, even those aimed at wisdom, cannot bring ultimate fulfillment without divine truth. True wisdom is ultimately a person—Christ Himself.

verses.text: For in much wisdom is much grief, and he who increases knowledge increases sorrow.
verses.comment: The burden of knowledge echoes the effects of the Fall (see Genesis 3). Divine wisdom—the kind found only with God’s guidance and through His appointed teachers—turns grief into hope through redemption.
